newsitem.title: FRANCE: Doubts said to delay Aerospatiale missiles merger.
newsitem.headline: Doubts said to delay Aerospatiale missiles merger.

text.p: A merger of the missiles businesses of Aerospatiale and Daimler-Benz Aerospace (DASA) needs more clarity over political priorities and the course of French defence restructuring for it to move forward, a European defence executive said on Tuesday.

"We want clear decisions on (missile) programmes so we can plan for the next two to three years. We need to know the government's priorities," the executive, speaking on grounds on anonymity, said at the Euronaval warship trade exhibition.
SNI Aerospatiale and DASA have been negotiating for at least two years to complete parallel mergers of their missiles and satellite businesses, but have so far not closed the deals.

The Wall Street Journal said on Tuesday that DASA was re-evaluating the planned Franco-German missiles merger following Paris's stated preference to sell Thomson SA to Lagardere, which would create a new force in the French missiles industry by combining Matra with Thomson-CSF.
"We need more information on the French defence industry restructuring," the executive said.
For example, one of the uncertainties is what will happen to Aerospatiale's missiles division when the group is privatised, he said.
Lagardere wants to be the natural centre for a European missiles and satellites business and has joint ventures with British Aerospace in missiles and GEC Plc in satellites.
It sees itself as the better partner for Germany, rather than Aerospatiale.

The next Franco-German summit due in early December is expected to give some political direction on a number of co-operation programmes, including the Tiger and NH90 helicopters, the Trigat and Polyphem missiles and the Helios II spy satellite.
"We need a political framework," the executive said.
At the programme level, meanwhile, Aerospatiale and DASA are continuing to develop new products.

The two companies announced on Tuesday their Vesta project, a technology demonstrator for the next generation of supersonic anti-ship missiles, which is due to enter full-scale development in 1998 and will go into service in 2005.
